columns.text: In this problem, we will use the concept of break-even to solve for the price per unit of the given product based on the given credit policy.

Substituting the known values to the formula above, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Cash flow}&=\dfrac{(1,340-1,320)\times(P^*-\$131)}{0.0085}\\[15 pt]
&=\dfrac{20P^*-\$2,620}{0.0085}\\
\end{aligned}$$

We can leave this as is for now since we are not yet solving for the final answer.

We also need to solve for the cost of switching to the new policy. This can be solved using this formula:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Cost}&=\text{Cost per unit of new policy}\times (\text{New policy quantity}-\text{Old policy quantity})\\
&+\text{Price of old policy}\times\text{Old policy quantity}
\end{aligned}$$

Substituting the values, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Cost}&=\$98\times(1,340-1,320)+\$131\times1,320\\
&=\$174,8880
\end{aligned}$$

The cost of switching to the new policy is $\$174,880$

Since we know that in order to get the break-even point, the net present value must be zero, we can simply equate the cash flow and the cost to each other since a zero NPV means that the cash flow and the costs are equal. We will then have:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Cash flow}&=\text{Cost}\\[15 pt]
\dfrac{20P^*-\$2,620}{0.0085}&=\$174,880
\end{aligned}$$

We can then isolate the unknown by cross-multiplication and adding $\$2,620$ on both sides.
$$\begin{aligned}
20P^*-\$2,620&=\$174,880\times 0.0085\\[15 pt]
20P^*&=\$1,486.48+\$2,620\\[15 pt]
20P^*&=\$4,106.48
\end{aligned}$$

We can then divide both sides by $20$ to get the break-even price per unit.

$$\begin{aligned}
P^*&=\dfrac{\$4,106.48}{20}\\[15 pt]
&=\$205.32
\end{aligned}$$

The break-even price per unit is $\$205.32$
